fields.Title of Contribution: Examining the Prevalence of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) Among Justice-Involved Youth in the U.S.: The Importance of Accounting for Race/Ethnicity, Gender, and Gendered Racial/Ethnic Groups
fields.Description/Abstract: <br>Background: Youth in the U.S. juvenile justice system are exposed to adverse childhood<br>experiences (ACEs) at higher rates than youth in the general public. Additionally, research has demonstrated ACEs can vary by race/ethnicity and gender. However, little is known about how ACEs are experienced across gendered racial/ethnic groups of justice-involved youth.<br>Objective: To address this gap, this exploratory study is the first to apply an intersectional lens<br>to examine the prevalence of ACEs among a group of justice-involved youth in the U.S.<br>Participants & Setting: Using secondary data, this study examines ACEs by gender,<br>race/ethnicity, and six gendered racial/ethnic groups of justice-involved youth referred to the<br>Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS) in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.<br>Methods: Descriptive analyses are presented by gender and race/ethnicity separately, followed<br>by gendered racial/ethnic groups to understand differential rates of exposure to ACEs.<br>Results: The study's findings align with previous research and reinforce that justice-involved<br>youth experience higher rates of adversity than the general public. The results also support the<br>feminist pathway’s perspective within an intersectional context, emphasizing the importance of<br>accounting for race/ethnicity and gender simultaneously to identify the unique experiences of<br>ACEs among justice-involved youth.<br>Conclusion: Recommendations related to these findings and considerations surrounding ACE<br>measures are discussed. Specifically, findings from this study stress the importance of<br>accounting for gender and race/ethnicity simultaneously when measuring experiences of<br>adversity. This is a critical step to providing equitable treatment and services to address trauma-related needs across gendered racial/ethnic groups of system-involved youth.
